fields.headline: Mothers Pride yields £475m
fields.bodyText: Food group RHM returned to the stock market yesterday with a £1bn valuation after a 13-year absence. Shares in the group, whose products include Mothers Pride bread, rose more than 6% from their opening price of 275p to close at 292.5p. The opening price was near the top of the stock's 228p-285p indicated price range and the issue was six times oversubscribed. In the first day of trading, more than 100m shares changed hands. The company is viewed as a low-risk defensive stock, with the shares yielding some 5.4%. The IPO was London's second largest float of the past two years, after poker group Partygaming, which joined the exchange last month. Formerly known as Ranks Hovis McDougall, RHM owns a portfolio of brands including Mr Kipling, Hovis, Paxo, Robertson's, Sharwoods and Bisto. It claims 98% of UK households have at least one of its products in the kitchen cupboard. It also makes own-label products for Asda, Tesco, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose. The chief executive, Ian McMahon, said he was "delighted" by the response to the float. "We have a strategy to continue RHM's transformation into the leading UK-focused food company and we are determined to create value for our shareholders by executing this strategy successfully." The £1.02bn valuation at the end of the first day's trading is exactly in line with analysts' expectations. The group had sales of £1.53bn in the year to the end of April. RHM, which was established 130 years ago as a flour miller, was acquired by Doughty Hanson five years ago. The private equity group will keep a substantial stake. Some £475m was raised from the float, of which £125m will go to the RHM pension fund to cut its deficit by half; the proceeds will also be used to cut RHM's debt to £711m. Doughty Hanson and RHM management and employees sold shares worth £136m. Charlie Bonham, an analyst at Oriel Securities, described RHM as "probably the best quality high yielder in the sector" and set a target for the shares of 330p for the next year.
